item.title: Obama, Gina Haspel, Texas: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: China, North Korea, Pope Francis: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Divisions Within Trump Team Undercut Quick Trade Victory With China
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in January. He said Sunday that the United States would hold off on imposing tariffs on China. Hours later, a trade official threatened the opposite.
item.description: Ceaseless infighting and jockeying for influence on the White House’s trade team helped deprive Mr. Trump of a quick victory on his most cherished policy agenda.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and ANA SWANSON

item.title: Trump’s Charm and Threats May Not Be Working on China. Here’s Why.
item.media:description: On Monday, President Trump promoted his administration’s trade talks with China as a success, saying on Twitter that they would lead China to buy more American agricultural goods.
item.description: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In China, Photo of Trade Talks Embodies ‘Young’ Country Passing Aging U.S.
item.description: Social media users noticed a distinct age gap between the Chinese delegates and the American lawmakers who met them in Washington.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: News Analysis: Trump Team’s Mueller Strategy: Limit the Investigation and Attack the Investigators
item.media:description: President Trump’s new strategy appears to be aimed at turning the focus away from the conduct of the president to that of his pursuers, while laying out a series of red lines to limit the reach and duration of the Russia investigation.
item.description: “They have now decided that they need to be more proactive, more aggressive and more anticipatory,” says Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor emeritus.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: News Analysis: By Demanding an Investigation, Trump Challenged a Constraint on His Power
item.media:description: Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, met with President Trump and other senior law enforcement and intelligence officials at the White House on Monday.
item.description: The president escalated his campaign to undermine the Justice Department’s traditional independence from White House interference.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Republican Leaders Will Be Allowed to See Some Information on Russia Investigation
item.media:description: Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who is overseeing the Russia inquiry, leaving the White House on Monday.
item.description: Intelligence and law enforcement officials had said the information was highly delicate and that it was not appropriate to turn over unredacted material to Congress.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and NICHOLAS FANDOS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Unsheltered: What You Need to Know as a New York Tenant
item.description: The city’s housing system can be complicated to navigate. Here’s a quick primer on what your rights are and how to exercise them.
item.dc:creator: GRACE ASHFORD

item.title: How to Win an Election in Venezuela: Control the Food
item.description: Subsidized eggs and frozen chickens may help to explain why President Nicolás Maduro stayed in power. Our correspondents followed his supporters as they enticed undernourished citizens to vote for Mr. Maduro in exchange for food.

item.title: Police Confronted Texas School Gunman Within 4 Minutes, Sheriff Says
item.media:description: Dr. David Marshall, left, and Dr. Gulshan Sharma spoke at a hospital in Galveston, Tex., about the injuries suffered by Officer John Barnes during the school shooting in Santa Fe, Tex., on Friday. Dr. Sharma gestured to the area where Officer Barnes was hit by a shotgun blast.
item.media:credit: Kelsey Walling/The Galveston County Daily News, via Associated Press
item.description: The Galveston County Sheriff said officers responding to the shooting at Santa Fe High hemmed the gunman into one classroom and saved lives by drawing his fire.
item.dc:creator: JACK HEALY

item.title: A Unique American Ritual: The School Shooting
item.description: From the University of Texas in 1966, to Columbine and now Santa Fe, the images of school shootings across America are almost indistinguishable.
item.category: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

item.title: Can Parents Be Charged for Failing to Keep Their Guns Locked Up?
item.media:description: A sign asking for more peace and fewer guns was part of a makeshift memorial outside Sante Fe High School on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.description: Texas is one of 14 states with a “negligent storage law,” which can make parents liable for crimes committed with their firearms by their children.
item.dc:creator: ADEEL HASSAN

item.title: Bankers Hate the Volcker Rule. Now, It Could Be Watered Down.
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve and other regulators will soon propose significant changes to the Volcker Rule, making it easier for large banks to engage in trading that can be highly profitable but also very risky.
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.description: Softening the rule, which prohibits banks from making speculative but profitable wagers, is part of the White House’s deregulatory push.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FLITTER and ALAN RAPPEPORT
item.category: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

item.title: Neal Katyal: Can’t Indict a President? That Could Hurt Trump
item.media:description: Protesters in Portland, Ore., at the National March for Impeachment in January.
item.media:credit: Diego Diaz/Icon Sportswire, via Getty Images
item.description: Rudolph Giuliani’s assertion would mean the president must testify.
item.dc:creator: NEAL K. KATYAL
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Trump v. the Department of Justice
item.description: President Trump and his enablers in Congress and the right-wing media are engaged in a dangerous campaign to undermine the foundations of American justice.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: What’s the Matter With Europe?
item.media:description: Supporters of the populist Five Star Movement celebrated its strong showing in Italy’s general elections in March.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: A discredited elite and dark forces rising. Sound familiar?
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

item.title: On Campus: Why Being a Foster Child Made Me a Conservative
item.description: My experiences forced me to reflect on what environments are best for children. Certainly not the ones I came from.
item.dc:creator: ROB HENDERSON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Stop Giving Trump the Benefit of the Doubt
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House last week.
item.description: The Korean summit meeting is a mess. Just like everything else.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE GOLDBERG
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: What Moral Heroes Are Made Of
item.description: What traits do those dedicated to improving society share?
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: Editorial Observer: Pompeo’s Iran Plan: Tell Them to Give Up
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo speaking at the Heritage Foundation on Monday.
item.description: The new secretary of state is engaging in wishful thinking after President Trump renounced the nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: CAROL GIACOMO

item.title: Opinion: Supreme Court Deals a Blow to Workers
item.media:description: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that companies can use arbitration clauses in employment contracts to bar workers from going to court over back wages or other workplace problems.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Employees who are underpaid, harassed or discriminated against have been left to press their cases alone in arbitration.
item.dc:creator: TERRI GERSTEIN and SHARON BLOCK

item.title: Venezuela’s Sham Election
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, center, greeted supporters after the election results were announced.
item.description: Sunday’s vote giving Nicolás Maduro another term was flawed by low turnout and rampant corruption. Venezuela’s Latin neighbors must unite to isolate and force him from office.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: In Hard-Line Speech, Pompeo Criticizes Iran’s Behavior
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo delivered a remarkably hard-line speech about Iran, offering no concessions to European leaders who want to do business with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Hundreds in Oakland Turn Out to BBQ While Black
item.media:description: Lamont Patton cooked up a feast at the BBQing While Black event on Sunday at Lake Merritt in Oakland, Calif.
item.media:credit: Laura A. Oda/East Bay Times, via Associated Press
item.description: The event was held at Lake Merritt, where two black men were hassled for grilling. “It was a sea of love and blackness and food and fun,” an organizer said.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: Man Agrees to Plead Guilty to Killing 5 at Fort Lauderdale Airport
item.media:description: Esteban Santiago before his arraignment in federal court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last year. Prosecutors said he would plead guilty in order to avoid the death penalty.
item.description: Prosecutors say Esteban Santiago will plead guilty to 11 counts and serve five consecutive life sentences, followed by 120 years in prison, in connection with a 2017 rampage.
item.dc:creator: MATT STEVENS

item.title: Tesla Model 3 Goes Upscale, and Base-Price Buyers Must Wait
item.media:description: Tesla’s Model 3, between the larger Model S and Model X, in a San Diego showroom. So far the company has made only versions selling for $49,000 or more, but not the $35,000 base model.
item.description: Elon Musk, the electric-car company’s chief, said Tesla would lose money and die if it began selling the cheapest version of its mass-market car too soon.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Dozens Die in Karachi from Relentless Heat
item.media:description: A volunteer sprays water on people to keep them cool as temperatures reached 44 degrees Celsius (111.2 degrees Fahrenheit) in Karachi, Pakistan, on Monday.
item.description: The 15 million residents of Karachi, the Pakistani port city known as the concrete jungle, are enduring a heat wave with little relief in sight.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Dovey Johnson Roundtree, Barrier-Breaking Lawyer, Dies at 104
item.media:description: Dovey Johnson Roundtree outside the United States District Court in Washington, about 1985. “As a woman, and as a woman of color in an age when black lawyers had to leave the courthouse to use the bathrooms, she dared to practice before the bar of justice and was unflinching,” the co-author of her memoir said.
item.description: Though little recognized, Ms. Roundtree won advances for black people and women at the bar of justice, challenging the Jim Crow society she knew too well.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Hillary and Bill Clinton Go Separate Ways for 2018 Midterm Elections
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton and former President Bill Clinton arriving for the funeral of Barbara Bush in Houston last month. The couple has been largely absent from the 2018 midterm campaigns.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by David J. Phillip
item.description: Mrs. Clinton plans to endorse Andrew M. Cuomo for governor of New York this week. But elsewhere on the 2018 campaign trail, she and Mr. Clinton are not always welcome.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS and MATT FLEGENHEIMER

item.title: In Jersey City, It’s Kushner vs. Kushner in a Race to Develop
item.media:description: A view of Murray Kushner’s Journal Square tower in Jersey City. His estranged brother, Charles, has plans to build right nearby, but has yet to break ground.
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.description: Charles and Murray Kushner, famously estranged brothers, are each betting they can transform a gritty neighborhood. Can both win?
item.dc:creator: CHARLES V. BAGLI

item.title: Survivor of Halloween Terror Attack Says She Will Not Be a Victim
item.media:description: Rachel Pharn lives in West New York, N.J., across the river from where she was seriously injured in the Halloween terror attack in Manhattan. “The first week, I was in such disbelief that I was alive.”
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: Rachel Pharn, 26, was sideswiped by a pickup truck in the October attack on a Manhattan bicycle path that left eight people dead and 11 others injured.
item.dc:creator: JAN RANSOM

item.title: Madame Pele, Hawaii’s Goddess of Volcanoes, Awes Those Living in Lava’s Path
item.media:description: Stefani Hinkle honored Madame Pele, the Hawaiian goddess of volcanoes and fire, in Kapoho, Hawaii.
item.description: Expressing reverence for their deity, many living in Kilauea’s shadow welcome its eruption — even when it destroys their home.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and TAMIR KALIFA

item.title: Fashion’s Woman Problem
item.description: Why is it that an industry aimed at women and buoyed by female dollars is still run mostly by men? A new study tries to find out.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN
item.category: Council of Fashion Designers of America

item.title: Venice Journal: A Chance to Spend 99-Plus Years in Venice (in the Afterlife)
item.media:description: The San Michele cemetery in Venice is the resting place of numerous celebrities as well as Venetians of all classes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Even if you canȁ#x2019;t afford a palazzo on the Grand Canal, you might be able to bid for a plot in the cemetery of San Michele.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: How Smarter Living Taught Me to Be an Adult
item.media:description: Tim Herrera, the editor of The Times's Smarter Living section.
item.media:credit: Joe Carrotta for The New York Times
item.description: Four things I’ve learned that can help you, too.
item.dc:creator: TIM HERRERA

item.title: What to Cook: What to Cook This Week
item.media:description: Fish fry (chepa vepudu).
item.media:credit: Gentl and Hyers for The New York Times. Food stylist: Frances Boswell. Prop stylist: Amy Wilson.
item.description: Make a great new recipe for a simple fish fry from Archana Pidathala, and maybe knock out a black-bean soup for the days ahead.
item.dc:creator: SAM SIFTON

item.title: A Beginner’s Guide to Backing Up Photos
item.description: Whether they’re digital photos on your smartphone or old negatives in your attic, here’s how to get started tackling your photo clutter.
item.dc:creator: TERRY SULLIVAN

item.title: Phys Ed: How Strenuous Exercise Affects Our Immune System
item.description: Marathons or other vigorous events are unlikely to make you vulnerable to colds afterward, according to a myth-busting review of the latest science.
item.dc:creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: How a Digital Rabbit Hole Gave Midori Takada’s 1983 Album a Second Life
item.media:description: The Japanese composer and percussionist Midori Takada released “Through the Looking Glass” in 1983. Three decades later, a YouTube algorithm introduced it to a world of new listeners.
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.description: “Through the Looking Glass” sold poorly upon its release, but a YouTube algorithm later brought it fresh attention; now the Japanese musician is on a U.S. tour.
item.dc:creator: ANDY BETA

item.title: Robert Indiana, 89, Who Turned ‘Love’ Into Enduring Art, Is Dead
item.media:description: Robert Indiana mixed paint in front of a design for a poster for the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center in 1964.
item.description: Mr. Indiana’s depiction of the letters L, O, V and E was one of the best-known images of the 20th century, widely reproduced but also widely imitated.
item.dc:creator: JORI FINKEL

item.title: Andy Warhol’s Interview Magazine Shuts Down
item.media:description: Interview magazine, founded by Andy Warhol, told employees on Monday that it was closing and filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy.
item.media:credit: Richard Lautens/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.description: The publication is filing for bankruptcy, according to an associate editor at the magazine.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Nonfiction: A Battle for the ‘Soul of America’? It’s as Old as America, One Historian Notes
item.media:description: A mural depicting Frederick Douglass petitioning President Lincoln to enlist African Americans in the Union Army. (William Edouard Scott, 1943.)
item.media:credit: Carol M. Highsmith/Buyenlarge, via Getty Images
item.description: In his new book, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Jon Meacham argues that in bad times a liberal impulse has often prevailed over fear and division.
item.dc:creator: SEAN WILENTZ

item.title: Q. & A.: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Making Good Time With the Pony Express
item.description: Jim DeFelice talks about “West Like Lightning,” his new history of the short-lived but long-remembered company and how it changed the United States.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS
item.category: West Like Lightning: The Brief, Legendary Ride of the Pony Express (Book)

item.title: Alien Asteroids Are Here, Scientists Say. Get Used to Them.
item.media:description: Images of the asteroid 2015 BZ509 obtained at the Large Binocular Telescope Observatory near Safford, Ariz. Called “BZ” for short, it orbits the sun in the opposite direction of the planets.
item.description: An asteroid that cohabits an orbit with Jupiter came from outside the solar system.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Doctors: My Patient’s Smile
item.description: I’m drawn to the human brain, its unforgiving and protean nature.
item.dc:creator: ABDUL-KAREEM AHMED

item.title: Trilobites: The Thing Inside Your Cells That Might Determine How Long You Live
item.media:description: A colored transmission electron micrograph of a human serous cell’s nucleus, with its nucleolus in purple. The nucleolus functions as the sort of brain of the nucleus, making rRNA, a basic ingredient for making proteins.
item.description: You may have forgotten about the nucleolus since you took biology class, but scientists think this structure inside every cell in your body may play an important role in aging.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN
